Screen.Title: HOW DO YOU RATE HEALTHCARE IN AUSTRALIA?

Video.Title: Meet Leith
Video.Text:
Leith is one of 2500 health professionals employed by Medibank to deliver 1.5 million healthcare interactions each year.
As a registered nurse with more than 25 years’ experience, Leith helps patients across Australia via the nation’s largest telephone triage, health advice and referral service. Through the service, nurses like Leith assess callers based on their symptoms before providing advice and recommendations on what care they need. Just one telehealth nurse can support 6,000 patients each year.
Like 85% of Medibank’s nurse workforce, Leith works from home thanks to Medibank’s unique work@home model. For Leith, it’s a win-win. She gets to stay active in the workforce while also being at home with her four teenage children.
“I can work from home during the day, then pick the kids up from school, help with homework, get dinner on the table, then do a few more hours of work once my husband gets home,” Leith said.
“The work-life balance is brilliant and it also means I can work more hours than I could in a hospital, plus you don’t have to travel,” Leith said.
For Medibank it means we’re tapping into an underutilised health workforce, putting years of experience and skills to good use to help relieve the burden on the public health system.
In fact, the triage, health advice and referral service results in 60,000 fewer emergency department visits, 5,000 fewer ambulance callouts and savings of almost $30 million in public healthcare costs Leith thinks that’s pretty cool, and we do too. Because at Medibank, we’re about better health choices, a better health system and better health outcomes for all Australians.

Screen.Title: A BETTER AUSTRALIA

slide.title: How many hours a day do you use a screen?
slide.subtitle: Drag the hands to show your usage

slide.text: A NEW MEDIBANK STUDY FINDS WE’RE AVERAGING NINE HOURS A DAY LOOKING AT SCREENS.
AUSTRALIAN ADULTS ARE SPENDING MORE TIME IN FRONT OF SCREENS THAN SLEEPING.

graphstate.bottomText: More than 60% of respondents with children agreed that screen time affects their family time, and their family's health.
57% of these want to cut back on screen time.
And one in five say that if they weren't in front of a screen they would be involved in a physical activity instead such as going for a run, riding a bike or going for a walk.

slide.text: HOW DOES THIS IMPACT OUR HEALTH

slide.featuredText: For this study, 1505 Australians were asked about their views on screen usage and its impact on health.

box.topText: A clear conclusion has been found: people suspect there is something concerning about the amount of time they spend in front of screens, but they are uncertain about exactly what the health impact is.

There is uncertainty about health risks. While 62% of respondents know that reduced physical activity is a consequence of too much screen time, almost half of those surveyed failed to recognise the likelihood of other health risks, which include obesity, attention difficulty, low self-esteem and depression.

“Much greater community education is needed around what are safe levels of screen time and more programs are needed to encourage people to unplug and get involved in other recreational activities.”
Dr Ian Boyd, Medibank

“The benefits of unplugging and spending more time being active are clear for both adults and children, and we need to be encouraging this before people accept our over-use of screens as the norm.”
Dr Ian Boyd, Medibank

graphstate.bottomText: Every year, more than one in five Australians experiences a mental illness.
Almost half the Australian population will experience a mental illness at some point in their life.

graphstate.featuredText: Australian adults will suffer from anxiety.

box.text: Australians take their own life every day. Almost double the national road toll.

box.topText: Suicide is Australia's biggest health crisis for people between 15 and 44.

graphstate.featuredText: Cost every year to support people with a mental illness in Australia, not including indirect costs like lost productivity.

slide.text: MENTAL HEALTH IS AN ISSUE CLOSE TO THE HEART OF MEDIBANK.
AND WE BELIEVE AUSTRALIA HAS AN UNPRECEDENTED OPPORTUNITY TO MEET THE MENTAL HEALTH CHALLENGE

slide.text: WE'RE EMBRACING A HEALTHIER WAY OF WORKING.

intro.cornerText: Here at Medibank, to live our ‘For Better Health’ purpose, we are embracing a healthier way of working that will help us to be more collaborative and productive… All part of Generation Better.

textstate.text: Leith is a registered nurse with more than 25 years’ experience.
One of 2,500 health professionals employed by Medibank.

As part of the nation’s largest telephone triage, health advice and referral service, Leith assesses callers based on their symptoms before providing advice and recommendations on what care they need.

slide.text: JUST ONE TELEHEALTH NURSE CAN SUPPORT 6,000 PATIENTS EACH YEAR.
Like 85% of Medibank’s nurse workforce, Leith works from home as part of our work@home model.

textstate.text: Every year, the service results in 60,000 fewer emergency department visits.
And savings of almost $30 million in public healthcare costs.
